The **New Zealand dollar** ([sign](/wiki/Currency_sign "Currency sign"): **$**
; [code](/wiki/ISO_4217 "ISO 4217"): **NZD**)
([Māori](/wiki/M%C4%81ori_language "Māori language"): _Tāra o Aotearoa_) is
the [currency](/wiki/Currency "Currency") and [legal
tender](/wiki/Legal_tender "Legal tender") of [New Zealand](/wiki/New_Zealand
"New Zealand"), the [Cook Islands](/wiki/Cook_Islands "Cook Islands"),
[Niue](/wiki/Niue "Niue"), the [Ross Dependency](/wiki/Ross_Dependency "Ross
Dependency"), [Tokelau](/wiki/Tokelau "Tokelau"), and a British territory, the
[Pitcairn Islands](/wiki/Pitcairn_Islands "Pitcairn Islands").[1] Within New
Zealand, it is almost always abbreviated with the [dollar
sign](/wiki/Dollar_sign "Dollar sign") ($), with "NZ$" sometimes used to
distinguish it from other [dollar](/wiki/Dollar "Dollar")-denominated
currencies. In the context of currency trading, it is often informally called
the "Kiwi",[2] since New Zealand is commonly associated with the indigenous
bird and the [one-dollar coin](/wiki/New_Zealand_one-dollar_coin "New Zealand
one-dollar coin") depicts a [kiwi](/wiki/Kiwi "Kiwi").

Introduced in 1967, the dollar is subdivided into 100
[cents](/wiki/Cent_\(currency\) "Cent \(currency\)"). Altogether there are ten
denominations—five coins and five banknotes—with the smallest being the
[10-cent coin](/wiki/New_Zealand_ten-cent_coin "New Zealand ten-cent coin").
Formerly there were lower denominations, but those were discontinued due to
inflation and production costs.

The New Zealand dollar is consistently one of the 10 most-traded currencies in
the world, being approximately 2.0% of global foreign exchange market daily
turnover in 2013.[3]

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=New_Zealand_dollar&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: History")]

###
Introduction[[edit](/w/index.php?title=New_Zealand_dollar&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Introduction")]

Prior to the introduction of the New Zealand dollar in 1967, the [New Zealand
pound](/wiki/New_Zealand_pound "New Zealand pound") was the currency of New
Zealand, which had been distinct from the [pound
sterling](/wiki/Pound_sterling "Pound sterling") since 1933. The pound used
the [£sd](/wiki/%C2%A3sd "£sd") system, in which the pound was divided into 20
shillings and one shilling was divided into 12 pence, which by the 1950s was
considered complicated and cumbersome.

[Switching to decimal currency](/wiki/Decimalisation "Decimalisation") had
been proposed in New Zealand since the 1930s, although only in the 1950s did
any plans come to fruition. In 1957, a committee was set up by the Government
to investigate decimal currency. The idea fell on fertile ground, and in 1963,
the Government decided to decimalise New Zealand currency.[4] The [Decimal
Currency
Act](/w/index.php?title=Decimal_Currency_Act_1964&action=edit&redlink=1
"Decimal Currency Act 1964 \(page does not exist\)") was passed in 1964,
setting the date of transition to 10 July 1967.[5] Words such as "fern",
"kiwi" and "zeal" were proposed to avoid confusion with the word "dollar",
which many people at the time associated with the [United States
dollar](/wiki/United_States_dollar "United States dollar").[6][7] In the end,
the word "dollar" was chosen anyway, and an
[anthropomorphic](/wiki/Anthropomorphic "Anthropomorphic") dollar note cartoon
character called "Mr. Dollar" became the symbol of transition in a huge
publicity campaign.[8]

On Monday 10 July 1967 ("Decimal Currency Day"), the New Zealand dollar was
introduced to replace the pound at a rate of two dollars to one pound (one
dollar to ten shillings, ten cents to one shilling,  5⁄6 cent to a penny).[9]
Some 27 million new banknotes were printed and 165 million new coins were
minted for the changeover.[6]

### Exchange
rate[[edit](/w/index.php?title=New_Zealand_dollar&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Exchange rate")]

The New Zealand dollar was initially pegged to the [US dollar](/wiki/US_dollar
"US dollar") at US$1.43 = NZ$1. This rate changed on 21 November of the same
year to US$1.12 = NZ$1 after the devaluation of the British pound (see
[Bretton Woods system](/wiki/Bretton_Woods_system "Bretton Woods system")),
although New Zealand devalued more than the UK.[10]

In 1971 the US devalued its dollar relative to gold, leading New Zealand on 23
December to peg its dollar at US$1.216 with a 4.5% fluctuation range, keeping
the same gold value. From 9 July 1973 to 4 March 1985 the dollar's value was
determined from a trade-weighted basket of currencies.

The NZ$ [was floated](/wiki/Floating_exchange_rate "Floating exchange rate")
on 4 March 1985 at the initial rate of US$0.4444. Since then the dollar's
value has been determined by the financial markets, and has been in the range
of about US$0.39 to 0.88.

The dollar's post-float low was US$0.3922 on 22 November 2000, and it reached
a post-float high on 9 July 2014 of US$0.8821. Much of this medium-term
variation in the exchange rate has been attributed to differences in interest
rates.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_]

The New Zealand dollar's value is often strongly affected by [currency
trading](/wiki/Foreign_exchange_market "Foreign exchange market"),[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] and is
among the 10 most-traded currencies.[11]

On 11 June 2007 the [Reserve Bank](/wiki/Reserve_Bank_of_New_Zealand "Reserve
Bank of New Zealand") sold an unknown worth of New Zealand dollars for nine
billion [USD](/wiki/USD "USD") in an attempt to drive down its value. This is
the first intervention in the markets by the Bank since the float in 1985.

Two suspected interventions followed, but they were not as successful as the
first: the first appeared to be initially effective, with the dollar dropping
to approximately US$0.7490 from near US$0.7620. However, within little more
than a month it had risen to new post-float highs, reaching US$0.8103 on 23
July 2007.

After reaching its post-float record high in early 2008, the value of the NZ$
plummeted throughout much of the 2nd half of 2008 and the first quarter of
2009 as a response to the global economic downturn and flight by investors
away from "riskier" currencies such as the NZ$. The NZ$ bottomed out at
approximately US$0.50 on 6 March 2009.[12] However, it rebounded strongly as
the year progressed, reaching the US$0.75 range by November 2009.[12]

By late 2012, the dollar was holding above 80 US cents, occasionally reaching
85c, prompting calls from [the Green Party](/wiki/Green_Party_of_New_Zealand
"Green Party of New Zealand") for [quantitative
easing](/wiki/Quantitative_easing "Quantitative easing").[13][14] Unions also
called on the Government and the [Reserve
Bank](/wiki/Reserve_Bank_of_New_Zealand "Reserve Bank of New Zealand") to take
action, but as of February 2013 both had declined.[15]

As of early June, 2017, the NZD was trading at approximately US$0.71.[16]

## Coins[[edit](/w/index.php?title=New_Zealand_dollar&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Coins")]

Main article: [Coins of the New Zealand
dollar](/wiki/Coins_of_the_New_Zealand_dollar "Coins of the New Zealand
dollar")

### History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=New_Zealand_dollar&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: History")]

On the introduction of the dollar, coins came in denominations of 1c, 2c, 5c,
10c, 20c, and 50c. The 1c and 2c coins were bronze, the others were [cupro-
nickel](/wiki/Cupronickel "Cupronickel").[17] To ease transition, the 5c, 10c
and 20c were the same size as the sixpence, shilling and florin that they
respectively replaced. Until 1970 the 10c coin bore the additional legend "One
Shilling". The obverse designs of all the coins featured [Arnold
Machin](/wiki/Arnold_Machin "Arnold Machin")'s portrait of [Queen Elizabeth
II](/wiki/Elizabeth_II "Elizabeth II"), with the legend ELIZABETH II NEW
ZEALAND [date]. The reverse sides of coins introduced in 1967 did not follow
the designs that were originally intended for them. Those [modern
art](/wiki/Modern_art "Modern art") and [sculpture](/wiki/Sculpture
"Sculpture") themed designs were leaked to a newspaper and met a very negative
public reaction. The final releases were given more conservative designs in
line with public expectations.

In 1986, New Zealand adopted [Raphael Maklouf](/wiki/Raphael_Maklouf "Raphael
Maklouf")'s new portrait of the Queen. The 1c and 2c coins were last minted
for circulation in 1987, with collector coins being made for 1988. The coins
were demonetised on 30 April 1990.[17] The lack of 1c and 2c coins meant that
cash transactions were normally rounded to the nearest 5c (10c from 2006), a
process known as [Swedish rounding](/wiki/Swedish_rounding "Swedish
rounding").

On 11 February 1991, aluminium-bronze $1 and $2 coins were introduced to
replace existing $1 and $2 notes.[17] In 1999, [Ian Rank-
Broadley](/wiki/Ian_Rank-Broadley "Ian Rank-Broadley")'s portrait of the Queen
was introduced and the legend rearranged to read NEW ZEALAND ELIZABETH II.

On 11 November 2004 the Reserve Bank announced that it proposed to take the 5c
coin out of circulation and to make the 50c, 20c and 10c coins smaller and use
plated steel to make them lighter. After a three-month public submission
period that ended on 4 February 2005, the Reserve Bank announced on 31 March
that it would go ahead with the proposed changes. The changeover period
started on 31 July 2006, with the old coins usable until 31 October 2006.[17]
The old 50c, 20c, 10c and 5c pieces are now no longer [legal
tender](/wiki/Legal_tender "Legal tender"), but are still redeemable at the
Reserve Bank. Prior to the change over these coins were similar, save for the
legend and reverse artwork, to international (mainly
[Commonwealth](/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations "Commonwealth of Nations")) coins
of the same British-derived sizes, which led to coins from other currencies,
particularly older coins, being accepted by vending machines and many
retailers.

##
Banknotes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=New_Zealand_dollar&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Banknotes")]

Main article: [Banknotes of the New Zealand
dollar](/wiki/Banknotes_of_the_New_Zealand_dollar "Banknotes of the New
Zealand dollar")

### History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=New_Zealand_dollar&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: History")]

In 1967, notes were introduced in denominations of $1, $2,
[$5](/wiki/New_Zealand_5_dollar_note "New Zealand 5 dollar note"),
[$10](/wiki/New_Zealand_Ten_dollar_Note "New Zealand Ten dollar Note"),
[$20](/wiki/New_Zealand_twenty_dollar_note "New Zealand twenty dollar note")
and [$100](/wiki/New_Zealand_100_dollar_note "New Zealand 100 dollar note"),
with all except the $5 replacing their pound predecessors. The original series
of dollar notes featured on the obverse a portrait of Queen Elizabeth II
wearing [Queen Alexandra](/wiki/Queen_Alexandra "Queen Alexandra")'s Kokoshnik
tiara, King George's VI festoon necklace, and Queen Mary's floret earrings,
while the reverse featured native birds and plants.[19] The notes were changed
slightly in 1981 due to a change of printer (from De La Rue to Bradbury,
Wilkinson & Co.) - the most noticeable difference being the portrait based
upon a photograph by Peter Grugeon, in which Queen Elizabeth II is wearing
Grand Duchess Vladimir's tiara and Queen Victoria's golden jubilee
necklace.[19] The [$50](/wiki/New_Zealand_50_dollar_note "New Zealand 50
dollar note") note was added in 1983 to fill the long gap between the $20 and
the $100 notes. $1 and $2 notes were discontinued in 1991 after being replaced
with coins.

A new series of notes was introduced in 1992. The obverse of each note
featured a notable New Zealander, while the reverse featured a native New
Zealand bird and New Zealand scenery. In 1999, [polymer
notes](/wiki/Polymer_notes "Polymer notes") replaced the paper notes. The
designs remained much the same, but were changed slightly to accommodate new
security features, with the most obvious changes being the two transparent
windows.

New banknotes are being printed in New Zealand at the moment. The new notes
are the same sizes and denominations as the older banknotes, and they will
continue to be made of the same flexible plastic material. The themes of the
notes remain the same, with the same respected New Zealanders, the Queen, and
flora and fauna remaining central to the designs. The $5 and $10 notes were
released in October 2015, with the $20, $50 and $100 notes set to release in
April 2016. The old New Zealand banknotes and the new 'Brighter Money'
banknotes can be used interchangeably for the time being.[20]

Since the older banknotes were first issued in 1999, security features and the
technology for designing and printing banknotes have all advanced
considerably. And while counterfeiting rates in New Zealand are low compared
to the rest of the world, the New Zealand public and government agree that it
is in the best interest to "stay one step ahead of the game", hence the new
notes.[20]

2015**_ , a “clear winner” among nearly 40 eligible designs from a record 20
countries. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand released the new $5 and $10 notes

Hillary facing the South Island’s Aoraki/Mount Cook, and, on the other side, a
rare yellow-eyed penguin and local flora.

## History of NZ$ foreign exchange rates in foreign
countries[[edit](/w/index.php?title=New_Zealand_dollar&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: History of NZ$ foreign exchange rates in foreign countries")]

With the breakdown of the Bretton Woods system in 1971, both Australia and New
Zealand converted the mostly-fixed foreign exchange regimes to a moving peg
against the US dollar.

In September 1974, Australia moved to a peg against a basket of currencies
called the [trade weighted index](/wiki/Trade_weighted_index "Trade weighted
index") (TWI) in an effort to reduce fluctuations associated with its peg to
the US dollar. The peg to the TWI was changed to a moving peg in November
1976, causing the actual value of the peg to be periodically adjusted.

Since the late 1990s, and certainly since the end of the [Cold
War](/wiki/Cold_War "Cold War") the US dollar has had less and less overall
influence over the value of both the NZ$ and A$ against other
currencies.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

The New Zealand dollar contributes greatly to the total global exchange market
- far in excess of New Zealand's relative share of population or global GDP.

According to the [Bank for International
Settlements](/wiki/Bank_for_International_Settlements "Bank for International
Settlements"), the New Zealand dollar's share of global foreign exchange
market daily turnover in 2016 was 2.1% (up from 1.6% in 2010) giving it a rank
of 11th.[3] Trading in the currency has climbed steadily since the same survey
in 1998 when the NZD's ranking was 17th and the share of turnover was just
0.2%.
